clinical_study.brief_title: Single Port Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy Versus Four Port Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy: Impact on Postoperative Pain

lead_sponsor.agency: Sacro Cuore Don Calabria General Hospital

clinical_study.source: Sacro Cuore Don Calabria General Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: This is a single-institution, prospective, randomized controlled trial. Subjects determined to need a cholecystectomy will be consented for surgery and study participation prior to enrollment in this study. Patients will then be randomized to receive either a single port laparoscopic cholecystectomy or a four port laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

detailed_description.textblock:
The main advantages of laparoscopic surgery are reduced postoperative pain, shorter hospital stay and the cosmetic result. Although reduced, however, pain is still substantial and constitutes the main clinical problem after laparoscopic cholecystectomy, in particular for future daily planned procedures.
Recently, a new technique of laparoscopic cholecystectomy has been developed, in which all instruments are inserted through the same port placed in the umbilical incision. This technique for cholecystectomy has been proved to be feasible and safe by several studies.
The purpose of the study is to compare postoperative pain, operating time, cosmetic result, between one port and standard laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

primary_outcome.measure: Post-operative pain scores (visual analogue pain scale from 0-10)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before surgery (baseline) and 2 hrs, 4 hrs, 6hrs, 12hrs, 24hrs and 48hrs after surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient-assessed cosmesis on the Visual Analogue Scale

intervention.intervention_name: Single port laparoscopic cholecystectomy SINGLE SITE LAPAROSCOPY ACCESS SYSTEM (Johnson & Johnson Medical Spa)
intervention.description: Single port laparoscopic cholecystectomy. SINGLE SITE LAPAROSCOPY ACCESS SYSTEM (Johnson & Johnson Medical Spa)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Biliary cholic
- Biliary dyskinesia
- Gallbladder polyps
- Other diagnosis at the discretion of the surgeon
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of Acute cholecystitis
- Jaundice
- Choledocolithiasis
- History of Pancreatitis
- Severe comorbidity
- BMI > 30
